snippet.textDisplay: I want to call Shenanigans on the menstrual cycle test. snippet.textDisplay: i think human's sleep and menstrual cycles are linked to the moon for a reason. Full moon are religiously significant events in most of the world (a little bit less in Christianity and Islam, but these are organized religions that reject nature worship), so we can probably be pretty sure that humans have been getting up to some kind of special activity once a month or at every full moon. Women might have been consuming natural medicines to control their fertility cycle, and have used the moon to keep track of that which could slowly adjust their cycle to match up tot he moon's. Wouldn't be weird if tens of thousands of years of this have caused humans to have an internal clock sense of the lunar cycle.
snippet.textOriginal: i think human's sleep and menstrual cycles are linked to the moon for a reason. snippet.textDisplay: A theory about menstrual phase locking correlates ovulation with the new moon phase. The increased likelihood of successful reproduction could be due to the tendency for early hominid multi-day hunting parties to correspond with the full moon. Thus, males home for the new moon and some consistency in the periodicity of menstruation with the cycle of phases promotes locking via reproductive success. Just a theory, but one that makes sense and  involves selective measures that are scientifically reliable. No way to prove many theories like this.
snippet.textOriginal: A theory about menstrual phase locking correlates ovulation with the new moon phase. The increased likelihood of successful reproduction could be due to the tendency for early hominid multi-day hunting parties to correspond with the full moon. Thus, males home for the new moon and some consistency in the periodicity of menstruation with the cycle of phases promotes locking via reproductive success. Just a theory, but one that makes sense and  involves selective measures that are scientifically reliable. No way to prove many theories like this.

snippet.textDisplay: Number 4 is a bit off. Tides result mainly from the moon position and not from it being full. Besides, the explanation is bit dubious... Does the attraction of the moon cause an atmospheric tide which in turn causes a rise in atmospheric pressure?... That doesn't seem to make much sense, since it's the gravitational pull from the moon counteracting the one from Earth that causes the tide in the first place...
snippet.textOriginal: Number 4 is a bit off. Tides result mainly from the moon position and not from it being full. Besides, the explanation is bit dubious... snippet.textDisplay: The oldest calendars were lunar calendars, but I’m sure the moon was used to monitor the passing of time before that.  I know it my own life, my sleep schedule is governed by weeks.  I get up around 4 or 5 in the morning on weekdays, while I’m not likely to wake until 9 or 10 on a weekend.  But then again, I’m naturally a night owl and the early rising schedule was forced upon me by work.  Still I can sleep right through my alarm clock on weekends.
snippet.textOriginal: The oldest calendars were lunar calendars, but I’m sure the moon was used to monitor the passing of time before that. snippet.textDisplay: 9:20 Seizures can be created in susceptible people because of rapid shifts in light levels, AKA flashing lights. If the light is higher, the dark and light contrast is less. So if something else is flashing, say a street light, but another source of light is present, say the full moon, then the effect will be less as chance to generate seizures. This is very much known about seizures so it's weird for people to speculate about melotonine levels when such obvious explanations are present.
snippet.textOriginal: 9:20 Seizures can be created in susceptible people because of rapid shifts in light levels, AKA flashing lights. If the light is higher,  the dark and light contrast is less. So if something else is flashing, say a street light, but another source of light is present, say the full moon, then the effect will be less as chance to generate seizures. This is very much known about seizures so it's weird for people to speculate about melotonine levels when such obvious explanations are present.

snippet.textDisplay: The chimpanzee thing proves nothing. Humans didn't evolve from chimpanzees. Even if you believe in evolution, chimpanzees are like a second or third cousin, species-wise. A common ancestor over a million years of development ago doesn't say anything about the development of proto-humans. It's bad speculative biology. Not surprised though, since Hank's field seems to be physics and he just bullshits the other fields of study. Also SciShow in general should not be taken on its face, it's very much PopSci. At best, it's slightly better than Bill Nye. Always do your own look into what they claim.
snippet.textOriginal: The chimpanzee thing proves nothing. Humans didn't evolve from chimpanzees. Even if you believe in evolution, chimpanzees are like a second or third cousin, species-wise. A common ancestor over a million years of development ago doesn't say anything about the development of proto-humans. It's bad speculative biology. Not surprised though, since Hank's field seems to be physics and he just bullshits the other fields of study. Also SciShow in general should not be taken on its face, it's very much PopSci. At best, it's slightly better than Bill Nye. Always do your own look into what they claim.

snippet.textDisplay:
Ancient man used to hunt during full moon, rather than sleep.
There's a lot of science proving the tidal effect on the water in our bodies during full moon. It amplifies emotions. That's why it's called a Hunter's moon and a Lover's moon. New moon does also, but rather than be prone to aggression - it's depression.
And, because full moon can increase blood pressure (tidal effect), there are surgeons who refuse to operate during full moon because of the possibility of excessive blood loss. So some of your myths, not so much.
snippet.textOriginal:
Ancient man used to hunt during full moon, rather than sleep.
There's a lot of science proving the tidal effect on the water in our bodies during full moon.  It amplifies emotions.  That's why it's called a Hunter's moon and a Lover's moon.  New moon does also, but rather than be prone to aggression - it's depression.
And, because full moon can increase blood pressure (tidal effect), there are surgeons who refuse to operate during full moon because of the possibility of excessive blood loss.  So some of your myths, not so much.

snippet.textDisplay: Remember. Before electric light, the easiest way to get around at night was to wait until the full moon. Hence why certain cultures plant/harvest based on lunar cycle. It's much more pleasant to do field work on a cool, moonlit, night vs on a hot summer afternoon. So we have developed a propensity to be more active during full moons.
snippet.textOriginal: Remember. Before electric light, the easiest way to get around at night was to wait until the full moon. Hence why certain cultures plant/harvest based on lunar cycle. It's much more pleasant to do field work on a cool, moonlit, night vs on a hot summer afternoon. So we have developed a propensity to be more active during full moons.

snippet.textDisplay: In my Nursing career I saw more patients pass away on full moon nights than any other moon formations. Anytime we had someone transfered to palliative care we always asked "is it a full moon", it was not being insensitive, it was to schedule a nurse to sit with the patient on Palliative care 24-7. It was not a wanted situation. But a known statistical occurance.

snippet.textDisplay: Regarding scorpions glowing in UV... if the mechanism (explanation) really is that they use their bodies to collect (otherwise invisible) UV light and then create visible (to them) light via fluorescence then there doesn’t necessarily need to be an explanation of why that particular pathway is best.*. It might well not be the *best way to do it... Evolution uses whatever is good enough to give an organism a reproductive advantage; perhaps the UV fluorescence pathway was a small change to an existing protein in the exoskeleton and that happened, instead of a larger change in the light detection proteins in the eye.
snippet.textOriginal: Regarding scorpions glowing in UV... if the mechanism (explanation) really is that they use their bodies to collect (otherwise invisible) UV light and then create visible (to them) light via fluorescence then there doesn’t necessarily need to be an explanation of why that particular pathway is *best.*. It might well not be the *best* way to do it... Evolution uses whatever is *good enough* to give an organism a reproductive advantage; perhaps the UV fluorescence pathway was a small change to an existing protein in the exoskeleton and that happened, instead of a larger change in the light detection proteins in the eye.

snippet.textDisplay: The hypothesis about epileptic seizures being more common when it's dark outside should be easy to test by looking at seizure rates in the wintertime versus the summertime in parts of the world close to the polar circle. In Scandinavia for instance, depending on how close to the polar circle you are you get little or no sunlight in the winter, and little or no darkness in the summer. So if the hypothesis is true then epileptic seizures should be more common in the winter in those parts of the world.
snippet.textOriginal: The hypothesis about epileptic seizures being more common when it's dark outside should be easy to test by looking at seizure rates in the wintertime versus the summertime in parts of the world close to the polar circle. In Scandinavia for instance, depending on how close to the polar circle you are you get little or no sunlight in the winter, and little or no darkness in the summer. So if the hypothesis is true then epileptic seizures should be more common in the winter in those parts of the world.

snippet.textDisplay:
I wonder if humans menstrual cycles are a similar length to the lunar one not because the moon is directly affecting the length, but because early women who were able to keep track of their cycles based on phases of the moon were at some selective advantage. That'd explain why the length matches, but no particular phase of the moon correlates to menstruation specifically.


ex: Women whose cycles matched the length of the lunar cycle were more easily able to predict when they were likely to conceive, Women who knew when they were likely to conceive could avoid having kids during hard times, having fewer kids means better survival outcomes for the children she does have, leading to more women being born with a roughly lunar length cycle.
snippet.textOriginal:
I wonder if humans menstrual cycles are a similar length to the lunar one not because the moon is directly affecting the length, but because early women who were able to keep track of their cycles based on phases of the moon were at some selective advantage. That'd explain why the length matches, but no particular phase of the moon correlates to menstruation specifically.


ex: Women whose cycles matched the length of the lunar cycle were more easily able to predict when they were likely to conceive, Women who knew when they were likely to conceive could avoid having kids during hard times, having fewer kids means better survival outcomes for the children she does have, leading to more women being born with a roughly lunar length cycle.

snippet.textDisplay:
9:30 Dung beetles don`t eat dung - their larvae do.

They package the dung and bury it in brood tunnels to lay eggs into, one per exactly measured dung-pill, and the larvae thus have nourishment for the starting phase of their life.
The adults of nearly all families of dung beetles prefer fresh foliage or fungi as nourishment. Only exception are Taurocerastinae.
snippet.textOriginal:
9:30    Dung beetles don`t eat dung - their larvae do.

They package the dung and bury it in brood tunnels to lay eggs into, one per exactly measured dung-pill,  and the larvae thus have nourishment for the starting phase of their life.
The adults of nearly all families of dung beetles prefer fresh foliage or fungi as nourishment. Only exception are Taurocerastinae.

snippet.textDisplay:
I have no personal experience with epilepsy; but if it was strictly the lower light level during the last quarter, then wouldn't there be more seizures at the dark of the moon, or in the first quarter, coming off the dark of the moon, rather than the last quarter, when we're coming off a full moon? Is it something to do with the drop in melatonin due to more light from the full moon, perhaps? Like if melatonin helps prevent them, then it would make sense that by the time we finally get around to the last quarter, one's levels would be the lowest, thanks to having gone through the full moon, and the build-up to it.


Which would mean that, historically speaking, one might not have more seizures during the full moon; but that it might herald a greater chance of them in the next few days, making it look like it was the moon causing the effect, if not necessarily immediately. But if it's the melatonin levels and their relationship to the levels of moonlight at the time, then it kind of does (as you said), which is intriguing.



That makes me wonder if there's a correlation between levels of light pollution and seizures. Do people have fewer seizures in rural areas? Would blackout curtains and a sleep mask lower the incidence of them in urban areas?


Fascinating topic!
snippet.textOriginal:
I have no personal experience with epilepsy; but if it was strictly the lower light level during the last quarter, then wouldn't there be more seizures at the dark of the moon, or in the first quarter, coming off the dark of the moon, rather than the last quarter, when we're coming off a full moon? Is it something to do with the drop in melatonin due to more light from the full moon, perhaps? Like if melatonin helps prevent them, then it would make sense that by the time we finally get around to the last quarter, one's levels would be the lowest, thanks to having gone through the full moon, and the build-up to it.


Which would mean that, historically speaking, one might not have more seizures *during* the full moon; but that it might herald a greater chance of them in the next few days, making it look like it was the moon causing the effect, if not necessarily immediately. But if it's the melatonin levels and their relationship to the levels of moonlight at the time, then it kind of does (as you said), which is intriguing.



That makes me wonder if there's a correlation between levels of light pollution and seizures. Do people have fewer seizures in rural areas? Would blackout curtains and a sleep mask lower the incidence of them in urban areas?


Fascinating topic!

snippet.textDisplay:
Regarding point one, I just recently wondered about full-moon related insomnia as my kid woke up at 2AM wanting to play.
I have I hypothesis - maybe full moon reflects not only visible light but also shorter wavelenghts such as UV? Maybe the excess of UV radiation during the night (most of our UV comes from the sun, so our bodies read UV - day, no UV - night) somehow messes up the synthesis of melatonin or just breaks our circadian rythm? That is actually a quite an interesting topic :)
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay:
So scorpions can't see UV light (tho neither can we) but they detect it with their shells and get the signal to hide.

We can't see infrared, but we feel it on our skin as heat. So our body tells us when to avoid infrared light and seek cooler areas.

Is say there was some convergent evolution, there.

If you haven't come to terms with this having been "designed" I can't possibly accept anything else you posit my friend. Good luck!

snippet.textDisplay: Great video, however go work in an ER during a full moon.

snippet.textDisplay: I’m surprised y’all didn’t mention babies being born on the full moon. I’ve always heard that it’s much more common by my nursing friends, I’m not sure if studies support that however.

snippet.textDisplay: Did the study used for #5 take into consideration medication? Just wondering, since medication like birth control completely changes cycles.
